sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using matrix methods
message_1:
Solve the system of linear equations using matrix method: 
$$
\begin{matrix} x+y+z=6 \\ 2x+3y+2z=15 \\ 3x+2y+z=13 \end{matrix}
$$
message_2:
To solve the system of linear equations using the matrix method, we first need to write the given system in the matrix form AX = B, where A is the matrix of coefficients, X is the column matrix of variables, and B is the column matrix of constants.

The given system can be written as:

$$
\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 3 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 6 \\ 15 \\ 13 \end{bmatrix}
$$

Now, we need to find the inverse of matrix A, denoted as A⁻¹. Then, we can find the solution by multiplying both sides of the equation by A⁻¹, which gives us X = A⁻¹B.

First, let's find the determinant of matrix A:

$$
\text{det}(A) = \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 3 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 & 1 \end{vmatrix} = 1\begin{vmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 \end{vmatrix} - 1\begin{vmatrix} 2 & 2 \\ 3 & 1 \end{vmatrix} + 1\begin{vmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 3 & 2 \end{vmatrix}
$$

$$
= 1(3 - 4) - 1(2 - 6) + 1(4 - 9) = -1 + 4 - 5 = -2
$$

Now, let's find the adjoint of matrix A:

$$
\text{adj}(A) = \begin{bmatrix} \begin{vmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 \end{vmatrix} & -\begin{vmatrix} 2 & 2 \\ 3 & 1 \end{vmatrix} & \begin{vmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 3 & 2 \end{vmatrix} \\ -\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 3 & 1 \end{vmatrix} & \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 3 & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\ \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 3 \end{vmatrix} & -\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 2 \end{vmatrix} & \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 3 \end{vmatrix} \end{bmatrix}
$$

$$
= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 4 & -3 \\ 2 & -2 & -1 \\ -1 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}
$$

Now, let's find the inverse of matrix A:

$$
A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\text{det}(A)} \cdot \text{adj}(A) = \frac{1}{-2} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 4 & -3 \\ 2 & -2 & -1 \\ -1 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -\frac{1}{2} & -2 & \frac{3}{2} \\ -1 & 1 & \frac{1}{2} \\ \frac{1}{2} & 0 & -\frac{1}{2} \end{bmatrix}
$$

Finally, let's find the solution X by multiplying A⁻¹ by B:

$$
X = A^{-1}B = \begin{bmatrix} -\frac{1}{2} & -2 & \frac{3}{2} \\ -1 & 1 & \frac{1}{2} \\ \frac{1}{2} & 0 & -\frac{1}{2} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 6 \\ 15 \\ 13 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}
$$

So, the solution to the system of linear equations is x = 1, y = 2, and z = 3.
